definitions.definition: Newly made, formed or evolved; having no precedent; of recent origin; new.
Original, especially in an interesting way; new and striking; not of the typical or ordinary type.
A work of prose fiction, longer than a novella.
A fable; a short tale, especially one of many making up a larger work.
A novelty; something new.
A new legal constitution in ancient Rome.
A person who is not susceptible to infection by a particular disease
To make immune.
(usually with "from") Exempt; not subject to.
definitions.example: As a diplomat, you are immune from prosecution.

definitions.definition: (usually with "to") Protected by inoculation, or due to innate resistance to pathogens.
definitions.example: I am immune to chicken pox.

definitions.definition: (by extension) Not vulnerable.
definitions.example: Alas, he was immune to my charms.

definitions.definition: Of or pertaining to the immune system.
definitions.example: We examined the patient's immune response.

definitions.definition: A fulfilment of a need or desire.
definitions.example: He enjoyed the dish with great satisfaction. He'll order it again the next time he arrives.

definitions.definition: The pleasure obtained by such fulfillment.
The source of such gratification.
A reparation for an injury or loss.
A vindication for a wrong suffered.
definitions.example: The count demanded satisfaction in the form of a duel at dawn.

definitions.definition: A place for discussion.
A gathering for the purpose of discussion.
A form of discussion involving a panel of presenters and often participation by members of the audience.
An Internet message board where users can post messages regarding one or more topics of discussion.
definitions.example: Trish was an admin on three forums, and had no trouble at all when it came to moderating them.

definitions.definition: A square or marketplace in a Roman town, used for public business and commerce.
The crime of stealing or otherwise illegally obtaining money by use of deception tactics.
Any act of deception carried out for the purpose of unfair, undeserved and/or unlawful gain.
The assumption of a false identity to such deceptive end.
A person who performs any such trick.
A trap or snare.
To defraud
A bond of unity or agreement between individuals, united around a common goal or against a common enemy, such as the unifying principle that defines the labor movement; mutual support within a group.
definitions.example: A long time union member himself, Phil showed solidarity with the picketing grocery store workers by shopping at a competing, unionized store.

definitions.definition: Willingness to give psychological and/or material support when another person is in a difficult position or needs affection.
definitions.example: Only the solidarity provided by her siblings allowed Margaret to cope with her mother's harrowing death.

definitions.definition: Relating to genetics or genes.
Caused by genes.
Of or relating to origin (genesis).
Based on shared membership in a linguistic family.
definitions.example: Chinese has borrowed several words from English, but it does not have a genetic relationship to English.

definitions.definition: Based on a shared membership in a religious family.
The act of settling.
The state of being settled.
A colony that is newly established; a place or region newly settled.
A community of people living together, such as a hamlet, village, town, or city.
The gradual sinking of a building. Fractures or dislocations caused by settlement.
The delivery of goods by the seller and payment for them by the buyer, under a previously agreed trade or transaction or contract entered into.
A disposition of property, or the act of granting it.
A settled place of abode; residence; a right growing out of legal residence.
A resolution of a dispute.
A person seeking refuge in a foreign country out of fear of political persecution or the prospect of such persecution in their home country, i.e., a person seeking political asylum.
A person seeking refuge due to a natural disaster, war, etc.
A person formally granted political or economic asylum by a country other than their home country.
(by extension) A person who flees one place or institution for another.
To convey (slaves) away from the advance of the federal forces.
A collimated stream, spurt or flow of liquid or gas from a pressurized container, an engine, etc.
A spout or nozzle for creating a jet of fluid.
A type of airplane using jet engines rather than propellers.
An engine that propels a vehicle using a stream of fluid as propulsion.
A part of a carburetor that controls the amount of fuel mixed with the air.
A narrow cone of hadrons and other particles produced by the hadronization of a quark or gluon.
Drift; scope; range, as of an argument.
The sprue of a type, which is broken from it when the type is cold.
To spray out of a container.
To spray with liquid from a container.
definitions.example: Farmers may either dip or jet sheep with chemicals.

definitions.definition: To travel on a jet aircraft or otherwise by jet propulsion
To move (running, walking etc.) rapidly around
To shoot forward or out; to project; to jut out.
To strut; to walk with a lofty or haughty gait; to be insolent; to obtrude.
To jerk; to jolt; to be shaken.
To adjust the fuel to air ratio of a carburetor; to install or adjust a carburetor jet
To leave.
Propelled by turbine engines.
definitions.example: jet airplane

definitions.definition: A hard, black form of coal, sometimes used in jewellery.
(color) The colour of jet coal, deep grey.
Very dark black in colour.
The act of neglecting.
The state of being neglected.
Habitual lack of care.
To fail to care for or attend to something.
definitions.example: to neglect duty or business;  to neglect to pay debts

definitions.definition: To omit to notice; to forbear to treat with attention or respect; to slight.
definitions.example: to neglect strangers

definitions.definition: To fail to do or carry out something due to oversight or carelessness.
The degree to which something fits.
definitions.example: Since he put on weight, his jeans have been a tight fit.

definitions.definition: Conformity of elements one to another.
definitions.example: It's hard to get a good fit using second-hand parts.

definitions.definition: The part of an object upon which anything fits tightly.
Measure of how well a particular commercial execution captures the character or values of a brand.
definitions.example: The Wonder Bread advertising research results showed the “White Picket Fence” commercial had strong fit ratings.

definitions.definition: Goodness of fit.
The quality of a partnership's combined holding of cards in a suit, particularly of trump.
definitions.example: During the auction, it is often a partnership's goal to find an eight-card major suit fit.

definitions.definition: To be suitable for.
definitions.example: It fits the purpose.

definitions.definition: To conform to in size and shape.
definitions.example: If I lose a few kilos, the gorgeous wedding dress might fit me.

definitions.definition: To be of the right size and shape
definitions.example: I wanted to borrow my little sister's jeans, but they didn't fit.

definitions.definition: (with to) To make conform in size and shape.
definitions.example: I want to fit the drapes to the windows.

definitions.definition: To be in agreement with.
definitions.example: These definitions fit most of the usage.

definitions.definition: To adjust.
definitions.example: The regression program fit a line to the data.

definitions.definition: To attach, especially when requiring exact positioning or sizing.
To equip or supply.
definitions.example: The chandler will fit us with provisions for a month.

definitions.definition: To make ready.
definitions.example: I'm fitting the ship for a summer sail home.

definitions.definition: To be seemly.
To be proper or becoming.
To be in harmony.
definitions.example: The paint, the fabrics, the rugs all fit.

definitions.definition: Suitable, proper.
definitions.example: You have nothing to say about it. I'll do exactly as I see fit.

definitions.definition: Adapted to a purpose or environment.
definitions.example: survival of the fittest

definitions.definition: In good shape; physically well.
definitions.example: You don't have to be a good climber for Kilimanjaro, but you do have to be fit.

definitions.definition: Sexually attractive; good-looking; fanciable.
definitions.example: I think the girl working in the office is fit.

definitions.definition: Prepared; ready.
A section of a poem or ballad.
A seizure or convulsion.
definitions.example: My grandfather died after having a fit.

definitions.definition: A sudden and vigorous appearance of a symptom over a short period of time.
A sudden outburst of emotion.
definitions.example: He had a laughing fit which lasted more than ten minutes.

definitions.definition: A sudden burst (of an activity).
To suffer a fit.
A minor fright.
definitions.example: Johnny had a bad scare last night.

definitions.definition: A cause of slight terror; something that inspires fear or dread.
definitions.example: a food-poisoning scare

definitions.definition: A device or object used to frighten.
To frighten, terrify, startle, especially in a minor way.
definitions.example: Did it scare you when I said "Boo!"?

definitions.definition: Lean; scanty
Careful; using or exercising caution; tentative
definitions.example: He took a few cautious steps toward the cave.

definitions.definition: The state or condition of having weight; weight; heaviness.
The state or condition of being grave; seriousness.
definitions.example: I hope you appreciate the gravity of the situation.

definitions.definition: The lowness of a note.
Force on Earth's surface, of the attraction by the Earth's masses, and the centrifugal pseudo-force caused by the Earth's rotation, resulting from gravitation.
(in casual discussion, also) Gravitation, universal force exercised by two bodies onto each other (gravity and gravitation are often used interchangeably).
Specific gravity.
Intense dread, fright, or fear.
The action or quality of causing dread; terribleness, especially such qualities in narrative fiction.
Something or someone that causes such fear.
Terrorism
definitions.example: a terror attack; the War on Terror

definitions.definition: Pus or exudate (other than blood) from a wound or orifice, usually due to infection or pathology.
The act of accomplishing (an obligation) or repaying a debt etc.; performance.
The act of expelling or letting go.
The act of firing a projectile, especially from a firearm.
The process of unloading something.
The process of flowing out.
The act of releasing an accumulated charge.
The act of releasing an inpatient from hospital.
The act of releasing a member of the armed forces from service.
The volume of water transported by a river in a certain amount of time, usually in units of m3/s (cubic meters per second).
To accomplish or complete, as an obligation.
To free of a debt, claim, obligation, responsibility, accusation, etc.; to absolve; to acquit; to forgive; to clear.
To send away (a creditor) satisfied by payment; to pay one's debt or obligation to.
To set aside; to annul; to dismiss.
To expel or let go.
To let fly, as a missile; to shoot.
To release (an accumulated charge).
To relieve of an office or employment; to send away from service; to dismiss.
To release legally from confinement; to set at liberty.
definitions.example: to discharge a prisoner

definitions.definition: To operate (any weapon that fires a projectile, such as a shotgun or sling).
To release (an auxiliary assumption) from the list of assumptions used in arguments, and return to the main argument.
To unload a ship or another means of transport.
To put forth, or remove, as a charge or burden; to take out, as that with which anything is loaded or filled.
definitions.example: to discharge a cargo

definitions.definition: To give forth; to emit or send out.
definitions.example: A pipe discharges water.

definitions.definition: To let fly; to give expression to; to utter.
definitions.example: He discharged a horrible oath.

definitions.definition: To bleach out or to remove or efface, as by a chemical process.
definitions.example: to discharge the colour from a dyed fabric in order to form light figures on a dark background

definitions.definition: To prohibit; to forbid.
The act or practice of admitting.
Permission to enter, or the entrance itself; admittance; entrance; access
definitions.example: I request admission for two adults

definitions.definition: The granting of an argument or position not fully proved; the act of acknowledging something asserted; acknowledgement; concession.

Acquiescence or concurrence in a statement made by another, and distinguishable from a confession in that an admission presupposes prior inquiry by another, but a confession may be made without such inquiry.
A fact, point, or statement admitted; as, admission made out of court are received in evidence
Declaration of the bishop that he approves of the presentee as a fit person to serve the cure of the church to which he is presented.
The cost or fee associated with attendance or entry.
definitions.example: There is no way he has seen that show, the admission is more than he makes in a week.

definitions.definition: One who pays a fee (rent) in return for the use of land, buildings, or other property owned by others.
One who has possession of any place.
One who holds a property by any kind of right, including ownership.
Any of a number of customers serviced through the same instance of an application.
To hold as, or be, a tenant.
To inhabit.
To cause to ingest (a drug), either by openly offering or through deceit.
definitions.example: We administered the medicine to our dog by mixing it in his food.

definitions.definition: To apportion out, distribute.
To manage or supervise the conduct, performance or execution of; to govern or regulate the parameters for the conduct, performance or execution of; to work in an administrative capacity.
To minister (to).
definitions.example: administering to the sick

definitions.definition: To settle, as the estate of one who dies without a will, or whose will fails of an executor.
To give, as an oath.
To give a drug to a patient, be it orally or by any other means.
To kill as punishment for capital crimes.
definitions.example: There are certain states where it is lawful to execute prisoners convicted of certain crimes.

definitions.definition: To carry out; to put into effect.
definitions.example: I'll execute your orders as soon as this meeting is adjourned.

definitions.definition: To perform.
definitions.example: to execute a difficult piece of music brilliantly

definitions.definition: To carry out, to perform an act; to put into effect or cause to become legally binding or valid (as a contract) by so doing.
definitions.example: to execute a contract

definitions.definition: To start, launch or run
definitions.example: to execute a program

definitions.definition: To run, usually successfully.
definitions.example: The program executed, but data problems were discovered.

definitions.definition: To work together with others to achieve a common goal.
definitions.example: Let's collaborate on this project, and get it finished faster.

definitions.definition: To voluntarily cooperate treasonably, as with an enemy occupation force in one's country.
definitions.example: If you collaborate with the occupying forces, you will be shot.

definitions.definition: To restrain within boundaries; to limit; to confine
definitions.example: After suffering diahrroea, the patient was restricted to a diet of rice, cold meat, and yoghurt.

definitions.definition: (specifically) To consider (a function) as defined on a subset of its original domain.
Restricted.
The complex joint between forearm bones, carpus, and metacarpals where the hand is attached to the arm; the carpus in a narrow sense.
A stud or pin which forms a journal.
To hit a wrist shot
The exercise of sovereign power.
definitions.example: England prospered under Elizabeth I's reign.

definitions.definition: The period during which a monarch rules.
definitions.example: The reign of Victoria was a long one.

definitions.definition: The territory or sphere over which a kingdom; empire; realm; dominion, etc. is ruled.
To exercise sovereign power, to rule as a monarch.
definitions.example: He reigned in an autocratic manner.

definitions.definition: To reign over (a country)
To be the winner of the most recent iteration of a competition.
To be a dominant quality of a place or situation; to prevail, predominate, rule.
definitions.example: Silence reigned.

definitions.definition: Having a bad reputation, disreputable; notoriously bad, unpleasant or evil; widely known, especially for something bad.
definitions.example: He was an infamous perjurer.

definitions.definition: Causing infamy; disgraceful.
definitions.example: This infamous deed tarnishes all involved.

definitions.definition: Subject to a judicial punishment that deprived the infamous person of certain rights; this included a prohibition against holding public office, exercising the franchise, receiving a public pension, serving on a jury, or giving testimony in a court of law.
A person who holds extreme views, especially one who advocates such views; a radical or fanatic.
Holding extreme views, especially on a political subject.
Of or relating to extremism.
A 42.195 kilometre (26 mile 385 yard) road race.
(by extension) Any extended or sustained activity.
definitions.example: He had a cleaning marathon the night before his girlfriend came over.

definitions.definition: To run a marathon.
To watch or read a large number of instalments of (a film, book, TV series, etc.) in one sitting.
definitions.example: We're going to marathon Star Trek next weekend.

definitions.definition: To get on a boat or ship or (outside the USA) an aeroplane.
definitions.example: All passengers please embark now.

definitions.definition: To start, begin.
definitions.example: Phil embarked on his journey yesterday.

definitions.definition: To cause to go on board a vessel or boat; to put on shipboard.
To engage, enlist, or invest (as persons, money, etc.) in any affair.
definitions.example: He embarked his fortune in trade.

definitions.definition: A carucate.
The act of carving
definitions.example: give that turkey a careful carve

definitions.definition: To cut.
To cut meat in order to serve it.
definitions.example: You carve the roast and I'll serve the vegetables.

definitions.definition: To shape to sculptural effect; to produce (a work) by cutting, or to cut (a material) into a finished work.
definitions.example: to carve a name into a tree

definitions.definition: To perform a series of turns without pivoting, so that the tip and tail of the snowboard take the same path.
To take or make, as by cutting; to provide.
To lay out; to contrive; to design; to plan.
The act of asserting; positive declaration or averment.
Something which is asserted; a declaration; a statement asserted.
definitions.example: You're a man of strong assertions!

definitions.definition: A statement or declaration which lacks support or evidence.
definitions.example: That's just a bare assertion.

definitions.definition: Maintenance; vindication
definitions.example: the assertion of one's rights or prerogatives

definitions.definition: A statement in a program asserting a condition expected to be true at a particular point, used in debugging.
Steadfast adherence to a strict moral or ethical code.
The state of being wholesome; unimpaired
The quality or condition of being complete; pure
With regards to data encryption, ensuring that information is not altered by unauthorized persons in a way that is not detectable by authorized users.
The ability of a system to provide timely warnings to users when they should not be used for navigation.
An organized culture encompassing many communities, often on the scale of a nation or a people; a stage or system of social, political or technical development.
definitions.example: Modern civilization is a product of industrialization and globalization.

definitions.definition: Human society, particularly civil society.
definitions.example: A hermit doesn't much care for civilization.

definitions.definition: The act or process of civilizing or becoming civilized.
definitions.example: The teacher's civilization of the child was no easy task.

definitions.definition: The state or quality of being civilized.
definitions.example: He was a man of great civilization.

definitions.definition: The act of rendering a criminal process civil.

Collectively, those people of the world considered to have a high standard of behavior and / or a high level of development. Commonly subjectively used by people of one society to exclusively refer to their society, or their elite sub-group, or a few associated societies, implying all others, in time or geography or status, as something less than civilised, as savages or barbarians. cf refinement, elitism, civilised society, the Civilised World
An inheritance; property that may be inherited.
A tradition; a practice or set of values that is passed down from preceding generations through families or through institutional memory.
A birthright; the status acquired by birth, especially of but not exclusive to the firstborn.
Having a certain background, such as growing up with a second language.
definitions.example: The university requires heritage Spanish students to enroll in a specially designed Spanish program not available to non-heritage students.

definitions.definition: An interruption to the regular flow or sequence of something.
A continuing act of disorder.
definitions.example: There was great disruption in the classroom when the teacher left.

definitions.definition: A breaking or bursting apart; a breach.
A person who works in a mine.
An operator of ordnance mines and similar explosives.
Any bird of one of four species of Australian endemic honeyeaters in the genus Manorina.
Any bird of one of several species of South American ovenbirds in the genus Geositta.
Software or hardware that mines, or creates new units of cryptocurrency.
The act of reviving, or the state of being revived
Renewed attention to something, as to letters or literature.
Renewed performance of, or interest in, something, such as drama or literature.
Renewed interest in religion, after indifference and decline; a period of religious awakening; special religious interest.
A Christian religious meeting held to inspire active members of a church body or to gain new converts.
Reanimation from a state of languor or depression; applied to health, a person's spirits, etc.
Renewed pursuit, or cultivation, or flourishing state of something, as of commerce, arts, agriculture.
Renewed prevalence of something, as a practice or a fashion.
definitions.example: the revival of hot pants

definitions.definition: Restoration of force, validity, or effect; renewal; reinstatement of a legal action.
definitions.example: the revival of a debt barred by limitation; the revival of a revoked will

definitions.definition: Revivification, as of a metal.
A long, thin piece of land; any long, thin area.
definitions.example: The countries were in dispute over the ownership of a strip of desert about 100 metres wide.

definitions.definition: (usually countable, sometimes uncountable) A long, thin piece of any material; any such material collectively.
definitions.example: I have some strip left over after fitting out the kitchen.

definitions.definition: A comic strip.
A landing strip.
A strip steak.
A street with multiple shopping or entertainment possibilities.
The playing area, roughly 14 meters by 2 meters.
The uniform of a football team, or the same worn by supporters.
A trough for washing ore.
The issuing of a projectile from a rifled gun without acquiring the spiral motion.
A television series aired at the same time daily (or at least on Mondays to Fridays), so that it appears as a strip straight across the weekly schedule.
The act of removing one's clothes; a striptease.
definitions.example: She stood up on the table and did a strip.

definitions.definition: (of games) Denotes a version of a game in which losing players must progressively remove their clothes.
definitions.example: strip poker; strip Scrabble

definitions.definition: To remove or take away, often in strips or stripes.
definitions.example: Norm will strip the old varnish before painting the chair.

definitions.definition: (usually intransitive) To take off clothing.
definitions.example: Seeing that no one else was about, he stripped and dived into the river.

definitions.definition: To perform a striptease.
definitions.example: In the seedy club, a group of drunken men were watching a woman stripping.

definitions.definition: To take away something from (someone or something); to plunder; to divest.
definitions.example: The athlete was stripped of his medal after failing a drugs test.

definitions.definition: To remove cargo from (a container).
To remove (the thread or teeth) from a screw, nut, or gear, especially inadvertently by overtightening.
definitions.example: Don't tighten that bolt any more or you'll strip the thread.

definitions.definition: To fail in the thread; to lose the thread, as a bolt, screw, or nut.
To remove color from hair, cloth, etc. to prepare it to receive new color.
To remove all cards of a particular suit from another player. (See also strip-squeeze.)
To empty (tubing) by applying pressure to the outside of (the tubing) and moving that pressure along (the tubing).
To milk a cow, especially by stroking and compressing the teats to draw out the last of the milk.
To press out the ripe roe or milt from fishes, for artificial fecundation.
To run a television series at the same time daily (or at least on Mondays to Fridays), so that it appears as a strip straight across the weekly schedule.
To pare off the surface of (land) in strips.
To remove the overlying earth from (a deposit).
To pass; to get clear of; to outstrip.
To remove the metal coating from (a plated article), as by acids or electrolytic action.
To remove fibre, flock, or lint from; said of the teeth of a card when it becomes partly clogged.
To pick the cured leaves from the stalks of (tobacco) and tie them into "hands".
To remove the midrib from (tobacco leaves).
Strength; power; might; force .
Intellectual power; skill; art.
(obsolete in the general sense) A work or product of art .
A device, a means; a magical device, spell or enchantment .
Learning of the schools, scholarship; a branch of learning or knowledge, a science, especially one of the ‘seven liberal arts’ of the medieval universities .
Skill, skilfulness, art, especially the skill needed for a particular profession .
definitions.example: The craft of writing plays.

definitions.definition: (plural crafts) A branch of skilled work or trade, especially one requiring manual dexterity or artistic skill, but sometimes applied equally to any business, calling or profession; the skilled practice of a practical occupation .
definitions.example: He learned his craft as an apprentice.

definitions.definition: A trade or profession as embodied in its practitioners collectively; the members of a trade or handicraft as a body; an association of these; a trade's union, guild, or ‘company’ .
definitions.example: She represented the craft of brewers.

definitions.definition: (plural craft) A vehicle designed for navigation in or on water or air or through outer space .
Implements used in catching fish, such as net, line, or hook. Modern use primarily in whaling, as in harpoons, hand-lances, etc. .
To make by hand and with much skill.
To construct, develop something (like a skilled craftsman).
definitions.example: state crafting; the process of crafting global policing

definitions.definition: To combine multiple items to form a new item, such as armour or medicine.
The organisation, identification and interpretation of sensory information.
Conscious understanding of something.
Vision (ability)
Acuity

(cognition) That which is detected by the five senses; not necessarily understood (imagine looking through fog, trying to understand if you see a small dog or a cat); also that which is detected within consciousness as a thought, intuition, deduction, etc.
An advocate of feminism; a person who believes in bringing about the equality of the sexes (of women and men) in all aspects of public and private life
A member of a feminist political movement
Relating to or in accordance with feminism.
The act of reducing to powder, or of sharpening, by friction.
Something that has been reduced to powder, something that has been ground.
A specific degree of pulverization of coffee beans.
definitions.example: This bag contains espresso grind.

definitions.definition: A tedious and laborious task.
definitions.example: This homework is a grind.

definitions.definition: A grinding trick on a skateboard or snowboard.
One who studies hard; a swot.
Grindcore (subgenre of heavy metal)
Hustle
To reduce to smaller pieces by crushing with lateral motion.
To shape with the force of friction.
definitions.example: grind a lens; grind an axe

definitions.definition: To remove material by rubbing with an abrasive surface.
To become ground, pulverized, or polished by friction.
definitions.example: Steel grinds to a sharp edge.

definitions.definition: To move with much difficulty or friction; to grate.
To slide the flat portion of a skateboard or snowboard across an obstacle such as a railing.
To oppress, hold down or weaken.
To rotate the hips erotically.
To dance in a sexually suggestive way with both partners in very close proximity, often pressed against each other.
To repeat a task a large number of times in a row to achieve a specific goal.
To operate by turning a crank.
definitions.example: to grind an organ

definitions.definition: To produce mechanically and repetitively as if by turning a crank.
To automatically format and indent code.
To instill through repetitive teaching.
definitions.example: Grinding lessons into students' heads does not motivate them to learn.

definitions.definition: To eat.
definitions.example: Eh, brah, let's go grind.

definitions.definition: To work or study hard; to hustle or drudge.
To annoy or irritate (a person); to grind one's gears.
A traditional communal pilot whale hunt in the Faroe Islands.
An enclosure within which workers, prisoners, or soldiers are confined
A group of buildings situated close together, e.g. for a school or block of offices
Anything made by combining several things.
A substance made from any combination elements.
A substance formed by chemical union of two or more ingredients in definite proportions by weight.
A lexeme that consists of more than one stem; compound word; for example laptop, formed from lap and top.
A compound locomotive, a steam locomotive with both high-pressure and low-pressure cylinders.
To form (a resulting mixture) by combining different elements, ingredients, or parts.
definitions.example: to compound a medicine

definitions.definition: To assemble (ingredients) into a whole; to combine, mix, or unite.
To modify or change by combination with some other thing or part; to mingle with something else.
To settle by agreeing on less than the claim, or on different terms than those stipulated.
definitions.example: to compound a debt

definitions.definition: To settle amicably; to adjust by agreement; to compromise.
To come to terms of agreement; to agree; to settle by a compromise; usually followed by with before the person participating, and for before the thing compounded or the consideration.
To compose; to constitute.
To increase in value with interest, where the interest is earned on both the principal sum and prior earned interest.
To worsen a situation.
Of a horse: to fail to maintain speed.
Composed of elements; not simple
definitions.example: a compound word

definitions.definition: Dealing with numbers of various denominations of quantity, or with processes more complex than the simple process
definitions.example: compound addition; compound proportion

definitions.definition: An octave higher than originally (i.e. a compound major second is equivalent to a major ninth).
The subject of an experiment.
Pertaining to or founded on experiment.
definitions.example: Chemistry is an experimental science.

definitions.definition: Serving to be experimented upon; used in an experiment.
Serving as an experiment; serving to experiment.
definitions.example: an experimental engine

definitions.definition: Experiential, empirical.
definitions.example: experimental knowledge

definitions.definition: A geographic area owned or controlled by a single person or organization.
definitions.example: The king ruled his domain harshly.

definitions.definition: A field or sphere of activity, influence or expertise.
definitions.example: Dealing with complaints isn't really my domain: get in touch with customer services.

definitions.definition: A group of related items, topics, or subjects.
The set of all possible mathematical entities (points) where a given function is defined.
The set of input (argument) values for which a function is defined.
A ring with no zero divisors; that is, in which no product of nonzero elements is zero.
An open and connected set in some topology. For example, the interval (0,1) as a subset of the real numbers.
Any DNS domain name, particularly one which has been delegated and has become representative of the delegated domain name and its subdomains.
A collection of DNS or DNS-like domain names consisting of a delegated domain name and all its subdomains.
A collection of information having to do with a domain, the computers named in the domain, and the network on which the computers named in the domain reside.
The collection of computers identified by a domain's domain names.
A small region of a magnetic material with a consistent magnetization direction.
Such a region used as a data storage element in a bubble memory.
(data processing) A form of technical metadata that represent the type of a data item, its characteristics, name, and usage.
The highest rank in the classification of organisms, above kingdom; in the three-domain system, one of the taxa Bacteria, Archaea, or Eukaryota.
A folded section of a protein molecule that has a discrete function; the equivalent section of a chromosome
One who is politically active in the role of a citizen; especially, one who campaigns for change.
One who is conspicuously active in carrying out any occupational or professional functions.
Behaving as an activist.
Receiving from someone's care what one has earlier entrusted to them. Usually refers to money.
A method of birth control which consists of removing the penis from the vagina before ejaculation.
A type of metabolic shock the body undergoes when a substance, usually a toxin such as heroin, to which a patient is dependent is withheld. Sometimes used with the substance as modifier.
definitions.example: caffeine withdrawal

definitions.definition: An act of withdrawing.
The sum of money taken from a bank account.
A vertical (or nearly vertical) rock face.
A point where something abruptly fails or decreases in value etc.
A symbol found on a musical staff that indicates the pitches represented by the lines and the spaces on the staff
Charming, pleasing qualities.
definitions.example: The Princess brought grace to an otherwise dull and boring party.

definitions.definition: A short prayer of thanks before or after a meal.
definitions.example: It has become less common to say grace before having dinner.

definitions.definition: In the games of patience or solitaire: a special move that is normally against the rules.
A grace note.
Elegant movement; balance or poise.
definitions.example: The dancer moved with grace and strength.

definitions.definition: An allowance of time granted to a debtor during which he or she is free of at least part of his normal obligations towards the creditor.
definitions.example: The repayment of the loan starts after a three-year grace.

definitions.definition: Free and undeserved favour, especially of God; unmerited divine assistance given to humans for their regeneration or sanctification, or for resisting sin.
definitions.example: I’m so grateful to God for the grace that He has given me.

definitions.definition: An act or decree of the governing body of an English university.
To adorn; to decorate; to embellish and dignify.
definitions.example: He graced the room by simply being there.

definitions.definition: To dignify or raise by an act of favour; to honour.
To supply with heavenly grace.
To add grace notes, cadenzas, etc., to.
To attack using one or more bombs; to bombard.
To fail dismally.
To jump into water in a squatting position, with the arms wrapped around the legs.
To sound; to boom; to make a humming or buzzing sound.
To cover an area in many graffiti tags.
To add an excessive amount of chlorine to a pool when it has not been maintained properly.
To make oneself drunk.
(especially with along, down, up etc.) To move at high speed.
definitions.example: I was bombing down the road on my motorbike.

definitions.definition: The action of dropping bombs from the air.
The action of placing and detonating bombs.
A reserve or substitute.
definitions.example: If the goalkeeper is injured, we have a backup.

definitions.definition: A copy of a file or record, stored separately from the original, that can be used to recover the original if it is destroyed or damaged.
definitions.example: After the power failure, we had to restore the database from backup.

definitions.definition: An accumulation of material caused by a (partial) obstruction or (complete) blockage of the flow or movement of the material, or an accumulation of material that causes an overflow due to the flow being greater than the maximum possible flow.
definitions.example: The accident caused a mile-long backup on the highway.

definitions.definition: (law enforcement) reinforcements
definitions.example: He's got a gun! You'd better send for backup.

definitions.definition: Standby, reserve or extra.
definitions.example: I am only a backup player.

definitions.definition: That is intended as a backup.
definitions.example: Make a backup copy of that file.

definitions.definition: Supporting, reinforcing; of or related to accompaniment
A place at which one is regularly found; a habitation or hangout.
definitions.example: I went back the town I used to live and visited all my old haunts.

definitions.definition: A ghost.
A feeding place for animals.
To inhabit, or visit frequently (most often used in reference to ghosts).
definitions.example: A couple of ghosts haunt the old, burnt-down house.

definitions.definition: To make uneasy, restless.
definitions.example: The memory of his past failures haunted him.

definitions.definition: To stalk, to follow
definitions.example: The policeman haunted him, following him everywhere.

definitions.definition: To live habitually; to stay, to remain.
To accustom; habituate; make accustomed to.
To practise; to devote oneself to.
To persist in staying or visiting.
A challenge to prove courage.
The quality of daring; venturesomeness; boldness.
Defiance; challenge.
To have enough courage (to do something).
definitions.example: I wouldn't dare argue with my boss.

definitions.definition: To defy or challenge (someone to do something)
definitions.example: I dare you (to) kiss that girl.

definitions.definition: To have enough courage to meet or do something, go somewhere, etc.; to face up to
definitions.example: Will you dare death to reach your goal?

definitions.definition: To terrify; to daunt.
To catch (larks) by producing terror through the use of mirrors, scarlet cloth, a hawk, etc., so that they lie still till a net is thrown over them.
To stare stupidly or vacantly; to gaze as though amazed or terrified.
To lie or crouch down in fear.
A small fish, the dace.
The act or process of calculating.
The result of calculating.
Reckoning, estimate.
definitions.example: By my calculation, we should be there by midnight.

definitions.definition: An expectation based on circumstances.
A relationship of resemblance or equivalence between two situations, people, or objects, especially when used as a basis for explanation or extrapolation.
The proportion or the equality of ratios.

(grammar) The correspondence of a word or phrase with the genius of a language, as learned from the manner in which its words and phrases are ordinarily formed; similarity of derivative or inflectional processes.
A vent or similar passage to allow the escape of something.
Something which allows for the release of one's desires.
A river that runs out of a lake.
A shop that sells the products of a particular manufacturer or supplier.
A wall-mounted device such as a socket or receptacle connected to an electrical system at which current is taken to supply utilization equipment or appliances.
A financial instrument issued by a municipality.
Of or pertaining to a municipality (a city or a corporation having the right of administering local government).
Of or pertaining to the internal affairs of a nation.
Sediment or rock that is not native to its present location or is different from the surrounding material. Sometimes refers to ore or gems.
That which is placed anywhere, or in anyone's hands, for safekeeping; something entrusted to the care of another.
Money placed in an account.
Anything left behind on a surface.
definitions.example: a deposit of seaweed on the shore

definitions.definition: A sum of money or other asset given as an initial payment, to show good faith, or to reserve something for purchase.
definitions.example: They put a deposit on the apartment.

definitions.definition: A sum of money given as a security for a borrowed item, which will be given back when the item is returned, e.g. a bottle deposit or can deposit
A place of deposit; a depository.
To lay down; to place; to put.
definitions.example: A crocodile deposits her eggs in the sand.

definitions.definition: To lay up or away for safekeeping; to put up; to store.
definitions.example: to deposit goods in a warehouse

definitions.definition: To entrust one's assets to the care of another. Sometimes done as collateral.
To put money or funds into an account.
To lay aside; to rid oneself of.
A person who organizes and operates a business venture and assumes much of the associated risk.
A person who organizes a risky activity of any kind and acts substantially in the manner of a business entrepreneur.
A person who strives for success and takes on risk by starting their own venture, service, etc.
To have a foolish affection for, to be fond of.
To caress; to fondle.
(chiefly with of) Having a liking or affection (for).
Affectionate.
definitions.example: a fond farewell

definitions.definition: Indulgent.
definitions.example: I have fond grandparents who spoil me.

definitions.definition: Outlandish; foolish; silly.
Foolish; simple; weak.
Doted on; regarded with affection.
The background design in lace-making.
Brown residue in pans from cooking meats and vegetables.
definitions.example: He used the fond to make a classic French pan sauce.

definitions.definition: A group of records having shared provenance.
Foundation; bottom; groundwork.
Fund, stock, or store.
Having or showing skill; skillful.
Requiring special abilities or training.
To set apart; separate.
To discern; have knowledge or understanding; to know how (to).
To know; to understand.
To have knowledge or comprehension; discern.
To have personal or practical knowledge; be versed or practised; be expert or dextrous.
To make a difference; signify; matter.
To spend acquired points in exchange for skills.
A deep, prolonged audible inhale and exhale of breath; as when fatigued, frustrated, grieved, or relieved; the act of sighing.
Figuratively, a manifestation of grief; a lament.
A person who is bored.

To inhale a larger quantity of air than usual, and immediately expel it; to make a deep single audible respiration, especially as the result or involuntary expression of fatigue, exhaustion, grief, sorrow, frustration, or the like.
definitions.example: He sighed over the lost opportunity.

definitions.definition: To lament; to grieve.
To utter sighs over; to lament or mourn over.
To experience an emotion associated with sighing.
definitions.example: He silently sighed for his lost youth.

definitions.definition: To make a sound like sighing.
To exhale (the breath) in sighs.
definitions.example: She sighed a sigh that was nearly a groan.

definitions.definition: To express by sighs; to utter in or with sighs.
definitions.example: "I guess I have no choice," she sighed.

definitions.definition: An expression of fatigue, exhaustion, grief, sorrow, frustration, or the like, often used in casual written contexts.
definitions.example: Sigh, I'm so bored at work today.

definitions.definition: (chiefly in the plural) An enemy.
Not friendly, appropriate to an enemy; showing the disposition of an enemy; showing ill will and malevolence, or a desire to thwart and injure
definitions.example: a hostile country

definitions.definition: Aggressive, antagonistic.
Unwilling
Of a hostile takeover.
definitions.example: Microsoft may go hostile in its bid for Yahoo as soon as Friday, according to a published report.

definitions.definition: The condition of being held in a state between two or more forces, which are acting in opposition to each other.
Psychological state of being tense.
A feeling of nervousness, excitement, or fear that is created in a movie, book, etc.; suspense.
State of an elastic object which is stretched in a way which increases its length.

Force transmitted through a rope, string, cable, or similar object (used with prepositions on, in, or of, e.g., "The tension in the cable is 1000 N", to convey that the same magnitude of force applies to objects attached to both ends).

Voltage. Usually only the terms low tension, high tension, and extra-high tension, and the abbreviations LT, HT, and EHT are used. They are not precisely defined; LT is normally a few volts, HT a few hundreds of volts, and EHT thousands of volts.
To place an object in tension, to pull or place strain on.
definitions.example: We tensioned the cable until it snapped.

definitions.definition: The ability to endure pain or hardship; endurance.
The ability or practice of tolerating; an acceptance of or patience with the beliefs, opinions or practices of others; a lack of bigotry.
The ability of the body (or other organism) to resist the action of a poison, to cope with a dangerous drug or to survive infection by an organism.
The variation or deviation from a standard, especially the maximum permitted variation in an engineering measurement.
definitions.example: Our customers can generally accept ten times the tolerance which we can achieve in our machining operations.

definitions.definition: The ability of the body to accept a tissue graft without rejection.
A status of possessing a thing or an office; an incumbency.
A period of time during which something is possessed.
A status of having a permanent post with enhanced job security within an academic institution.
A right to hold land under the feudal system.
To grant tenure, the status of having a permanent academic position, to (someone).
A person filled with or guided by enthusiasm.
A person exhibiting over-zealous religious fervour.
The act of accepting; a receiving of something offered, with acquiescence, approbation, or satisfaction; especially, favourable reception; approval.
definitions.example: the acceptance of a gift, office, doctrine, etc.

definitions.definition: Belief in something; agreement, assent.
The state of being accepted.
The usual or accepted meaning of a word or expression.
An assent and engagement by the person on whom a bill of exchange is drawn, to pay it when due according to the terms of the acceptance; the bill of exchange itself when accepted.

An agreeing to the action, proposals, or terms of another by some act which results in the conclusion of a legally binding contract; the reception or taking of a thing bought as that for which it was bought, or as that agreed to be delivered, or the taking of possession of a thing as owner.

The act of an authorized representative of the government by which the government assents to ownership of existing and identified supplies, or approves specific services rendered, as partial or complete performance of a contract.
A list of horses accepted as starters in a race.

A conserved property of the light in an optical system which characterizes how "spread out" the light is in terms of angle and area: it is the product of its cross-sectional area (normal to the direction of propagation) and the solid angle it subtends.
A member, normally elected, in the house or chamber of a legislature called a senate. The legislatures of the United States and Canada have senators.
A position in government held in ancient Rome by experienced, elder officials as advisors or consultants for younger, less experienced functionaries.
A member of the king's council.
The machines constituting a production apparatus, in a plant etc., collectively.
The working parts of a machine as a group.
The collective parts of something which allow it to function.
The literary devices used in a work, notably for dramatic effect
A law-enforcement official of the FBI; a federal agent.
A supporter of federation.
A unionist soldier in the American Civil War.
Pertaining to a league or treaty; derived from an agreement or covenant between parties, especially between nations.
Pertaining to the national government level, as opposed to state, provincial, county, city, or town.
Health, safety, happiness and prosperity; well-being in any respect.
Various forms of financial aid provided by the government to those who are in need of it (abbreviated form of welfare assistance).
Such payment.
To provide with welfare or aid.
definitions.example: welfaring the poor

definitions.definition: One that merges.
The act or process of merging two or more parts into a single unit.
definitions.example: Club mergers reduced the number of teams by half

definitions.definition: The legal union of two or more corporations into a single entity, typically assets and liabilities being assumed by the buying party.
An absorption of one or more estate(s) or contract(s) into one other, all being held by the same owner; of several counts of accusation into one judgement, etc.
A type of sound change where two or more sounds merge into one.
The emerging stem and embryonic leaves of a new plant.
A photography session.
A hunt or shooting competition.
An event that is unscripted or legitimate.
The act of shooting; the discharge of a missile; a shot.
A rush of water; a rapid.
A weft thread shot through the shed by the shuttle; a pick.
A shoat; a young pig.
A vein of ore running in the same general direction as the lode.
An inclined plane, either artificial or natural, down which timber, coal, ore, etc., are caused to slide; a chute.
The act of taking all point cards in one hand.
To launch a projectile.
To move or act quickly or suddenly.
To act or achieve.
To measure the distance and direction to (a point).
To inject a drug (such as heroin) intravenously.
To develop, move forward.
To protrude; to jut; to project; to extend.
definitions.example: The land shoots into a promontory.

definitions.definition: To plane straight; to fit by planing.
To variegate as if by sprinkling or intermingling; to color in spots or patches.W
To shoot the moon.
A mild expletive, expressing disbelief or disdain
definitions.example: Didn't you have a concert tonight?

definitions.definition: The action or process of making goods systematically or on a large scale.
Anything made, formed or produced; product.
The process of such production; generation, creation.
A watch manufacturer that makes its own parts, rather than assembling watches from parts obtained from other firms.
To make things, usually on a large scale, with tools and either physical labor or machinery.
To work (raw or partly wrought materials) into suitable forms for use.
definitions.example: to manufacture wool into blankets

definitions.definition: To fabricate; to create false evidence to support a point.
A publication that is published once a week.
Of or relating to a week.
Happening once a week, or every week.
definitions.example: He's going for his weekly check-up at the hospital.

definitions.definition: Once every week.
definitions.example: She visits her mother weekly.

definitions.definition: Every week.
The act of passing over, across, or through something.
The conveyance of people or goods from one place to another, especially on a public transportation system; the vehicles used for such conveyance.
definitions.example: the transit of goods through a country

definitions.definition: The passage of a celestial body across the observer's meridian, or across the disk of a larger celestial body.
A surveying instrument rather like a theodolite that measures horizontal and vertical angles.
An imaginary line between two objects whose positions are known. When the navigator sees one object directly in front of the other, the navigator knows that his position is on the transit.
A Ford Transit van, see Transit.
definitions.example: Beufort road, Birkenhead, about 17.15 June 19 2013, white transit overtakes and swerves left into junction almost taking my front wheel.

definitions.definition: Public transport system.
definitions.example: I always take the transit to work.

definitions.definition: To pass over, across or through something.
To revolve an instrument about its horizontal axis so as to reverse its direction.
To make a transit.

To carry communications traffic to and from a customer or another network on a compensation basis as opposed to peerage in which the traffic to and from another network is carried on an equivalency basis or without charge.
The feeling of annoyance when one's actions are criticized or hindered
The act of frustrating, or the state, or an instance of being frustrated
A thing that frustrates
Anger not directed at anything or anyone in particular
To create or make.
definitions.example: Earth was shapen by God for God's folk.

definitions.definition: To give something a shape and definition.
definitions.example: Shape the dough into a pretzel.   For my art project, I plan to shape my clay lump into a bowl.

definitions.definition: To form or manipulate something into a certain shape.
(of a country, person, etc) To give influence to.
To suit; to be adjusted or conformable.
To imagine; to conceive.
Having been given a shape, especially a curved shape.
definitions.example: The shaped sides of the wardrobe give it a more attractive appearance.

definitions.definition: (in compound terms) Having a particular shape (sharing the appearance of something in space, especially its outline – often a basic geometric two-dimensional figure)
To heap up in a mass; to pile up; to collect or bring together (either literally or figuratively)
definitions.example: He wishes to accumulate a sum of money.

definitions.definition: To grow or increase in quantity or number; to increase greatly.
To take a higher degree at the same time with a lower degree, or at a shorter interval than usual.
Collected; accumulated.
The act of aspiring or ardently desiring; an ardent wish or desire, chiefly after what is elevated or spiritual (with common adjunct adpositions being to and of).
definitions.example: Morgan has an aspiration of winning the game.

definitions.definition: The action of aspirating.
A burst of air that follows the release of some consonants.
To file a legal action against someone, generally a non-criminal action.
To seek by request; to make application; to petition; to entreat; to plead.
(of a hawk) To clean (the beak, etc.).
To leave high and dry on shore.
definitions.example: to sue a ship

definitions.definition: To court.
To follow.
The act of corrupting or of impairing integrity, virtue, or moral principle; the state of being corrupted or debased; loss of purity or integrity
The act of corrupting or making putrid, or state of being corrupt or putrid; decomposition or disorganization, in the process of putrefaction; putrefaction; deterioration.
The product of corruption; putrid matter.
The decomposition of biological matter.
The seeking of bribes.
The destruction of data by manipulation of parts of it, either by deliberate or accidental human action or by imperfections in storage or transmission media.
The act of changing, or of being changed, for the worse; departure from what is pure, simple, or correct.
definitions.example: a corruption of style

definitions.definition: A debased or nonstandard form of a word, expression, or text, resulting from misunderstanding, transcription error, mishearing, etc.
Something originally good or pure that has turned evil or impure; a perversion.
Any craft designed for transportation on water, such as a ship or boat.
A craft designed for transportation through air or space.
Dishes and cutlery collectively, especially if made of precious metals.
A container of liquid or other substance, such as a glass, goblet, cup, bottle, bowl, or pitcher.
A person as a container of qualities or feelings.
A tube or canal that carries fluid in an animal or plant.
definitions.example: Blood and lymph vessels are found in humans; xylem and phloem vessels are found in plants.

definitions.definition: To put into a vessel.
An open space between woods.
Ground (generally in front of or around a house) covered with grass kept closely mown.
An overgrown agar culture, such that no separation between single colonies exists.
A type of thin linen or cotton.
(in the plural) Pieces of this fabric, especially as used for the sleeves of a bishop.
A piece of clothing made from lawn.
A person, group, or state (etc) which is associated with another for a common cause; one united to another by treaty or common purpose; a confederate.
definitions.example: the two countries were allies in WWI

definitions.definition: A person, group, concept (etc) which is associated with another as a helper; a supporter; an auxiliary.
Anything akin to something else by structure, etc.
A closely related species, usually within the same family.
definitions.example: Gruiformes — cranes and allies

definitions.definition: A relative; a kinsman.
To unite, or form a connection between, as between families by marriage, or between princes and states by treaty, league, or confederacy.
To connect or form a relation between by similitude, resemblance, friendship, or love.
A narrow street or passageway, especially one through the middle of a block giving access to the rear of lots or buildings.
definitions.example: The parking lot to my friend's apartment building is in the alley.

definitions.definition: The area between the outfielders.
definitions.example: He hit one deep into the alley.

definitions.definition: An establishment where bowling is played.
An elongated wooden strip of floor along which a bowling ball is rolled.
The extra area between the sidelines or tramlines on a tennis court that is used for doubles matches.
A walk or passage in a garden or park, bordered by rows of trees or bushes.
A passageway between rows of pews in a church.
(perspective drawing) Any passage having the entrance represented as wider than the exit, so as to give the appearance of length.
The space between two rows of compositors' stands in a printing office.
A glass marble or taw.
A change of direction of motion after hitting the ground or an obstacle.
A movement up and then down (or vice versa), once or repeatedly.
An email return with any error.
The sack, licensing.
A bang, boom.
A drink based on brandyW.
A heavy, sudden, and often noisy, blow or thump.
Bluster; brag; untruthful boasting; audacious exaggeration; an impudent lie; a bouncer.
Scyliorhinus canicula, a European dogfish.
A genre of New Orleans music.
Drugs.
Swagger.
A 'good' beat.
A talent for leaping.
definitions.example: Them pro-ballers got bounce!

definitions.definition: To change the direction of motion after hitting an obstacle.
definitions.example: The tennis ball bounced off the wall before coming to rest in the ditch.

definitions.definition: To move quickly up and then down, or vice versa, once or repeatedly.
definitions.example: He bounces nervously on his chair.

definitions.definition: To cause to move quickly up and down, or back and forth, once or repeatedly.
definitions.example: He bounced the child on his knee.

definitions.definition: To suggest or introduce (an idea, etc.) to (off or by) somebody, in order to gain feedback.
definitions.example: I'm meeting Bob later to bounce some ideas off him about the new product range.

definitions.definition: To leap or spring suddenly or unceremoniously; to bound.
definitions.example: She bounced happily into the room.

definitions.definition: To move rapidly (between).
(of a cheque/check) To be refused by a bank because it is drawn on insufficient funds.
definitions.example: We can’t accept further checks from you, as your last one bounced.

definitions.definition: To fail to cover (have sufficient funds for) (a draft presented against one's account).
definitions.example: He tends to bounce a check or two toward the end of each month, before his payday.

definitions.definition: To leave.
definitions.example: Let’s wrap this up, I gotta bounce.

definitions.definition: To eject violently, as from a room; to discharge unceremoniously, as from employment.
(sometimes employing the preposition with) To have sexual intercourse.
(air combat) To attack unexpectedly.
definitions.example: The squadron was bounced north of the town.

definitions.definition: To turn power off and back on; to reset
definitions.example: See if it helps to bounce the router.

definitions.definition: (of an e-mail message or address) To return undelivered.
definitions.example: The girl in the bar told me her address was thirsty@example.com, but my mail to that address bounced back to me.

definitions.definition: To land hard and lift off again due to excess momentum.
definitions.example: The student pilot bounced several times during his landing.

definitions.definition: (skydiving) To land hard at unsurvivable velocity with fatal results.
definitions.example: After the mid-air collision, his rig failed and he bounced. BSBD.

definitions.definition: (sound recording) To mix (two or more tracks of a multi-track audio tape recording) and record the result onto a single track, in order to free up tracks for further material to be added.
definitions.example: Bounce tracks two and three to track four, then record the cowbell on track two.

definitions.definition: To bully; to scold.
To strike or thump, so as to rebound, or to make a sudden noise; to knock loudly.
To boast; to bluster.
The condition of being exposed, uncovered, or unprotected.
definitions.example: Limit your exposure to harsh chemicals.   Get as much exposure to a new language as you can.

definitions.definition: Lack of protection from weather or the elements.
The act of exposing something, such as a scandal.
That part which is facing or exposed to something, e.g. the sun, weather, sky, or a view.
definitions.example: They rented a cabin with a beautiful southern exposure.

definitions.definition: An instance of taking a photograph.
The piece of film exposed to light.
Details of the time and f-number used.
The amount of sun, wind etc. experienced by a particular site.
The deliberate commission of an act of violence to create public fear through the suffering of the victims in the furtherance of a political or social agenda.
The use of unlawful violence against people or property to achieve political objectives.

A form of psychological manipulation through warfare to the purpose of political or religious gains, by means of deliberately creating a climate of fear amongst the inhabitants of a specific geographical region.
The act of putting together; assembly.
A mixture or compound; the result of composing.
The proportion of different parts to make a whole.
The general makeup of a thing or person.
An agreement or treaty used to settle differences; later especially, an agreement to stop hostilities; a truce.
A payment of money in order to clear a liability or obligation; a settling or fine.
An agreement or compromise by which a creditor or group of creditors accepts partial payment from a debtor.
An essay.
The formation of compound words from separate words.
A work of music, literature or art.
Typesetting.
Applying a function to the result of another.
The compounding of two velocities or forces into a single equivalent velocity or force.
Consistency; accord; congruity.
Synthesis as opposed to analysis.
The arrangement and flow of elements in a picture.
Way to combine simple objects or data types into more complex ones.
A device that produces a monochromatic, coherent beam of light.
A beam of light produced by such a device; a laser beam.
A laser printer.
To cut with a laser
To throw with laser-like precision
A gum resin obtained from certain umbelliferous plants.
Such a plant.
To make sure and secure.
(followed by that or of) To give (someone) confidence in the trustworthiness of (something).
definitions.example: He assured of his commitment to her happiness.

definitions.definition: To guarantee, promise (to do something).
To reassure.
A formal, rhythmic way of walking, used especially by soldiers, bands and in ceremonies.
A political rally or parade
Any song in the genre of music written for marching (see Wikipedia's article on this type of music)
Steady forward movement or progression.
definitions.example: the march of time

definitions.definition: (euchre) The feat of taking all the tricks of a hand.
To walk with long, regular strides, as a soldier does.
To cause someone to walk somewhere.
To go to war; to make military advances.
To make steady progress.
A border region, especially one originally set up to defend a boundary.
A region at a frontier governed by a marquess.
Any of various territories with similar meanings or etymologies in their native languages.
To have common borders or frontiers
Smallage.
Great unhappiness; extreme pain of body or mind; wretchedness; distress; woe.
definitions.example: Ever since his wife left him you can see the misery on his face.

definitions.definition: A bodily ache or pain.
Cause of misery; calamity; misfortune.
(Extreme) poverty.
Greed; avarice.
A generally tubular invertebrate of the annelid phylum; an earthworm.
More loosely, any of various tubular invertebrates resembling annelids but not closely related to them, such as velvet worms, acorn worms, flatworms, or roundworms.
A type of wingless "dragon", especially a gigantic sea serpent.
Either a mythical "dragon" (especially wingless), a gigantic sea serpent, or a creature that resembles a Mongolian death worm.
A contemptible or devious being.
definitions.example: Don't try to run away, you little worm!

definitions.definition: A self-replicating program that propagates through a network.
A graphical representation of the total runs scored in an innings.
Anything helical, especially the thread of a screw.
Any creeping or crawling animal, such as a snake, snail, or caterpillar.
An internal tormentor; something that gnaws or afflicts one’s mind with remorse.
A strip of linked tiles sharing parallel edges in a tiling.
The lytta.
(preceded by definite article) A dance, or dance move, in which the dancer lies on the floor and undulates the body horizontally thereby moving forwards.
To make (one's way) with a crawling motion.
definitions.example: We wormed our way through the underbrush.

definitions.definition: To move with one's body dragging the ground.
To work one's way by artful or devious means.
To work (one's way or oneself) (into) gradually or slowly; to insinuate.
definitions.example: He wormed his way into the organization

definitions.definition: To effect, remove, drive, draw, or the like, by slow and secret means; often followed by out.
(in “worm out of”) To drag out of, to get information that someone is reluctant or unwilling to give (through artful or devious means or by pleading or asking repeatedly).
To fill in the contlines of (a rope) before parcelling and serving.
definitions.example: Worm and parcel with the lay; turn and serve the other way.

definitions.definition: To deworm (an animal).
To cut the worm, or lytta, from under the tongue of (a dog, etc.) for the purpose of checking a disposition to gnaw, and formerly supposed to guard against canine madness.
To clean by means of a worm; to draw a wad or cartridge from, as a firearm.
Something that motivates, rouses, or encourages.
definitions.example: I have no incentive to do housework right now.

definitions.definition: A bonus or reward, often monetary, to work harder.
definitions.example: Management offered the sales team a $500 incentive for each car sold.

definitions.definition: Inciting; encouraging or moving; rousing to action; stimulating.
Serving to kindle or set on fire.
A flattened mass of anything soft, to sit or lie on.
A cushion used as a saddle without a tree or frame.
A soft, or small, cushion.
A cushion-like thickening of the skin on the under side of the toes of animals.
The mostly hairless flesh located on the bottom of an animal's foot or paw.
Any cushion-like part of the human body, especially the ends of the fingers.
A stuffed guard or protection, especially one worn on the legs of horses to prevent bruising.
A soft bag or cushion to relieve pressure, support a part, etc.
A sanitary napkin.
A floating leaf of a water lily or similar plant.
A soft cover for a batsman's leg that protects it from damage when hit by the ball.
A kind of cushion for writing upon, or for blotting, especially one formed of many flat sheets of writing paper; now especially such a block of paper sheets as used to write on.
A panel or strip of material designed to be sensitive to pressure or touch.
A keypad.
A flat surface or area from which a helicopter or other aircraft may land or be launched.
An electrical extension cord with a multi-port socket one end: "trip cord"
The effect produced by sustained lower reed notes in a musical piece, most common in blues music.
A synthesizer instrument sound used for sustained background sounds.
A bed.
A small house, apartment, or mobile home occupied by a single person; such as a bachelor, playboy, etc.
A prison cell.
A random key (originally written on a disposable pad) of the same length as the plaintext.
A mousepad.
The amount by which a signal has been reduced.
A piece of timber fixed on a beam to fit the curve of the deck.
To stuff.
To furnish with a pad or padding.
To increase the size of, especially by adding undesirable filler.
definitions.example: May 21, 2008, Austin American-Statesman

definitions.definition: To imbue uniformly with a mordant.
definitions.example: to pad cloth

definitions.definition: To deliberately play the ball with the leg pad instead of the bat.
A toad.
A footpath, particularly one unformed or unmaintained; a road or track. See footpad.
An easy-paced horse; a padnag.
A robber that infests the road on foot; a highwayman or footpad.
A type of wickerwork basket, especially as used as a measure of fish or other goods.
To travel along (a road, path etc.).
To travel on foot.
To wear a path by walking.
To walk softly, quietly or steadily, especially without shoes.
To practise highway robbery.
The sound of soft footsteps, or a similar noise made by an animal etc.
Indicating a soft flat sound, as of bare footsteps.
definitions.example: I heard her soft footsteps, pad, pad along the corridor.

definitions.definition: The act of adopting.
The state of being adopted; the acceptance of a child of other parents as if he or she were one's own child.
definitions.example: A Chinese baby girl was given away for adoption.

definitions.definition: Admission to an institution, for example a hospital, clinic, mental asylum.
definitions.example: the adoption of people into hospitals or monasteries

definitions.definition: The choosing and making that to be one's own which originally was not so; acceptance
definitions.example: the adoption of opinions

definitions.definition: Transfer between an old system to another (usually better) system.
definitions.example: Our company is considering the adoption of a four-day week.

definitions.definition: An act of divine grace by which the redeemed in Christ are admitted to the privileges of the sons of God.
Ten consecutive wins against an opponent.
To ease (a person, person's thoughts etc.) from mental distress; to stop (someone) feeling anxious or worried, to alleviate the distress of.
definitions.example: I was greatly relieved by the jury's verdict.

definitions.definition: To ease (someone, a part of the body etc.) or give relief from physical pain or discomfort.
To alleviate (pain, distress, mental discomfort etc.).
To provide comfort or assistance to (someone in need, especially in poverty).
To lift up; to raise again.
To raise (someone) out of danger or from (a specified difficulty etc.).
To free (someone) from debt or legal obligations; to give legal relief to.
definitions.example: This shall not relieve either Party of any obligations.

definitions.definition: To bring military help to (a besieged town); to lift the siege on.
To release (someone) from or of a difficulty, unwanted task, responsibility etc.
(job) To free (someone) from their post, task etc. by taking their place.
To make (something) stand out; to make prominent, bring into relief.
To go to the toilet; to defecate or urinate.
Experiencing or exhibiting relief; freed from stress or discomfort.
definitions.example: She was extremely relieved when the lesson finished.

definitions.definition: To negatively criticize.
definitions.example: Quit harshing me already, I said that I was sorry!

definitions.definition: To put a damper on (a mood).
definitions.example: Dude, you're harshing my buzz.

definitions.definition: Unpleasantly rough to the touch or other senses.
Severe or cruel.
